You wouldn't be totally weightless on a trip to Mars like you would be on the ISS. On the ISS they're in constant freefall, so they experience no force in any direction whatsoever. However, on a trip to Mars you are not in freefall, you're being propelled in a specific direction and so there's an opposing force on your body which is equivalent to gravity. What percentage of Earth's gravity it is depends on your velocity, but as long as you're moving it's never gonna be zero.

Derek, since you're often in Australia, you could do this simple video experiment that proves definitively that the Earth is a globe. In the Southern hemisphere, if you follow your compass West for a while, a straight line from your starting point to your ending point will be to your South if the Earth is a globe, and to your North if the Earth is flat. In Southern Australia I figure you'd only have to walk a mile or two to see significant divergence. There are a variety of ways you could do this experiment, I'm sure you'd come up with something great. What I like about this experiment is that there's no confusion about perspective or atmospheric effects or complex calculations or anything like that. I've had a lot of success just explaining this experiment to Flat Earthers. They find it harder to believe such a massive conspiracy could exist when it's so easy to prove one way or the other.

I see flashes of light on earth with my eyes closed before going to bed whenever there is a sharp unexpected sound / click.  At first I thought it was an electrical spark from the automatic thermocouple on my air conditioner, possibly a hazard, but I could not see any light coming from the air conditioner if my eyes were open when the similar click happened.  I then noticed similar flashes occurred when there were other unexpected noises happening outside, many of which were not due to electronics.  I could not get similar flashes to occur when snapping my fingers, I guess because the noise that follows is an expected noise.  It is possible that the flashes were be due to the release of small bits of radiation released when electricity starts to flow through a circuit, but it does not explain the flashes seen after unexpected outdoor noises not related to electronics.  Also, the brightness of the flash does not seem to correlate to distance from the source of the noise.  I was wondering whether these flashes are a known physiological effect.

The effects on the body of long term lower gravity is so under discussed. The amount of hell a human body goes through in lower gravity may be the biggest inhibitor of manned flights to mars and beyond or long term habitats.
Blindness and extreme vision distortion, bloodflow problems, extreme muscle loss, fluid buildup where it shouldnt be, bone loss (and all the things that come with that).

Even exercise is not a replacement for the amount of "exercise" humans exert simply living on earths gravitational environment.

Another thing (especially important with simulated gravity like in a rotating habitat) going from one gravitational frame (1g) to microgravity causes the equilbrium and entire system our sense of balance and focus of the eyes causes debilitation in 50% of astronauts that takes a few days to adapt/correct. Imagine everytime you leave your habitat in 1g vomiting and nauseous for 48 hours and then when you get back feel the same way.

We also underestimate how absolutely safe we are inside our dense atmosphere. The radiation as you mentioned will undoubtedly cause huge health effects later. Cosmic rays (as learned on the moon missions with the silver coated black helmet) even interfere in your brain as they pass through causing flashs of light and lines in vision.

Derek, you keep using the word "microgravity". You are an educator. One of the best around. Why would you use this word that makes absolutely no sense. Just because NASA uses it?

Imagine that you had a measuring device in your pocket. You could read straight off the display exactly how much gravity is pulling on that meter at any moment. Then you graph the data. Would you still use the word "microgravity" after seeing very clearly on this graph that gravity never went to zero. It never got anywhere close to zero. And it never got into the "Micro-" range on this meter's scale? Fly a trip on the space shuttle. Fly a trip to the Moon. Fly a trip to Mars and back. NEVER does gravity get anywhere close to zero. This measuring device clearly shows you that the Sun has a HUGE pull on you the entire time, let alone the effect of all the other stuff around you.

So let's all please stop using very silly words. I realize that it FEELS like someone turned gravity off. But you've got enough knowledge in your brain to know that that didn't actually happen.

Long-term effects of 1/3 gravity? Has anyone done any significant research on the long term affects of 1/3 gravity on the human body? I find it unbelievable that we are Gearing up to spend so much money to go to Mar yet  this basic question doesn’t seem to be one that is being adequately researched.  The human body is not a linear system. We know that the human body cannot withstand zero gravity for extended periods of time such as year without staining irreversible damage. Why do we think that One third gravity would be OK? It might be just as bad as weightlessness. It might be the case that only when you reached three-quarter’s gravity does the human body adjust without suffering severe damage over long periods of time.  If this turns out to be the case, Mars may be completely useless for human colonization. We just don’t know and there’s no excuse for that.

On a trip to Mars, zero g is more of an engineering problem rather than a personal one.

Assembly of a ship in space with constant rotational pods maintaining 1G would eliminate the issues on the travel over.

Technology advancements in reactors, fuel loads, and reactors, may one day allow constant thrust of 1G throughout the journey, with the obvious flip near the halfway point for 'deceleration'.

And lastly the mythical future technology of gravity manipulation which may or may not ever become a thing.

We have the technology to overcome this challenge already, but it is easier (and cheaper) to simply have them run, tied to a treadmill, than it is to eliminate the problem entirely.

Just a comment on your final comment.... Living on Mars would only take human evolution in a 'different direction' [than intended/normal/otherwise/if remaining on Earth] if you believe in free will. If you don't believe in free will, which many don't, then living on Mars and other planets is indeed part of the natural progression of our evolution as a species. I tend to believe the latter concept. We're endowed with these enormous brains, and shitty, practically useless bodies if we were left to our own devices without our large brains. Our large brains is what makes us human, and therefore, our natural evolutionary progression is to create. It is to build. It is technological advancement. Tech and AI is human evolution, just as Frankenstein's monster is the creator.

The thing is, you would quickly become Martian. That is, to stay there would make returning incredibly dangerous and somewhat pointless. But reproducing naturally on planet might not be possible. Giving birth to a child might destroy the bone structure of the mother’s pelvis, so colonists would be dependent on artificial methods which do not readily present the bacteria inheritance that infants critically require for health. Lots of challenges, probably solvable but we should forget about Martian colonists still being human.
